title: Tracking tropics | Tropical Storm Ernesto forms in the Atlantic , warnings issued from Leeward Islands to Puerto Rico
message:
Tropical Storm Ernesto forms in the Atlantic, expected to impact Puerto Rico by midweek: NHCRALEIGH, N.C. (WTVD) -- Tropical Storm Ernesto formed in the Atlantic Ocean on Monday afternoon.
The storm is expected to bring tropical conditions to the Leeward Islands, Virgin Islands and Puerto Rico by Wednesday, according to the National Hurricane Center (NHC).
Ernesto could impact Bermuda but it's too soon to tell, the NHC said in a social media post.
On Sunday night, ABC11 Meteorologist Robert Johnson said the storm could move near Puerto Rico by midweek and curve north toward Bermuda as a hurricane between Thursday and Friday.
Hurricane Debby, which entered North Carolina as a tropical storm, weakened into a tropical depression, has moved out of the U.S. over the weekend.
event_breakdown: Tropical Storm Ernesto forms in the Atlantic, expected to impact Puerto Rico by midweek: NHC

title: Tropical Storm Warnings Issued For Puerto Rico , U . S . Virgin Islands
message:
Tropical Storm warnings have been issued for Puerto Rico and the U.S. Virgin Islands as Potential Tropical Cyclone Five churns in the Atlantic Ocean.
The cyclone is forecast to strengthen into Tropical Storm Ernesto by Tuesday (August 13) as it moves west toward the Leeward Islands.
"On the forecast track, the disturbance is expected to move across portions of the Leeward Islands late tonight or Tuesday and approach the U.S. and British Virgin Islands and Puerto Rico Tuesday evening," the National Hurricane Center said.
Meteorologists are warning the storm could bring up to ten inches of flooding rains and damaging winds to Puerto Rico before heading north and strengthening into a hurricane later in the week.
Most forecast models show the storm system will stay away from the East Coast of the U.S. as it strengthens in the mid-Atlantic.
event_breakdown:
1. Tropical Storm warnings have been issued for Puerto Rico and the U.S. Virgin Islands as Potential Tropical Cyclone Five churns in the Atlantic Ocean.
2. Meteorological agencies are warning that the storm could bring up to ten inches of flooding rains and damaging winds to Puerto Rico before heading north and strengthening into a hurricane later in the week.

The potential tropical cyclone that will eventually become Tropical Storm Ernesto is churning in the Atlantic Ocean. It is forecast to bring flooding rains and damaging winds to the U.S. Virgin Islands and Puerto Rico before heading north and strengthening into a hurricane later in the week.
The Spanish island of La Palma is bracing for a potential eruption from a volcano that has been active since September. Heavy rain could trigger more activity, experts warn.
Two earthquakes hit off the coast of British Columbia, Canada. The first one had a magnitude of 4.7 while the second registered as 5.7 One of the epicenters hit out at 10.3 kilometers from Port Hardy on Vancouver Island while the other was approximately 119 kilometers off the Queen Charlotte Islands.

Recommendation: Medium impact from AM5 expected in Myanmar. Storm has weakened and risk of landfall will remain low. No action required for now.

Modeling Data: The forecast movement is west-northwest at 15 to 25 mph.

Inconclusive

Wind Speed: 50 miles to 60 mph

Flooding Level: None

Peak Wind: 75 mph (scale 1-5)

Intensity: Current status is Moderate (scale 1-5)

The depression is currently about 650 miles south of the southern tip of Baja California and is expected to move west-northwest and then northwest over the coming days.
The storm is then forecast to turn north and then northeast, making landfall in Mexico late next week as a hurricane.
A potentially catastrophic Category 5 hurricane has formed in the Atlantic and is expected to become a major threat to Bermuda by the end of the week.
Super Typhoon Chanthu, which had previously been downgraded to a Category 3 storm, has since rapidly intensified into a Category 5 storm and is expected to impact the northern Philippines in the next few days.

title: Tropical Storm Warnings Issued For Puerto Rico , U . S . Virgin Islands
message:
Tropical Storm warnings have been issued for Puerto Rico and the U.S. Virgin Islands as Potential Tropical Cyclone Five churns in the Atlantic Ocean.
The cyclone is forecast to strengthen into Tropical Storm Ernesto by Tuesday (August 13) as it moves west toward the Leeward Islands.
"On the forecast track, the disturbance is expected to move across portions of the Leeward Islands late tonight or Tuesday and approach the U.S. and British Virgin Islands and Puerto Rico Tuesday evening," the National Hurricane Center said.
Meteorologists are warning the storm could bring up to ten inches of flooding rains and damaging winds to Puerto Rico before heading north and strengthening into a hurricane later in the week.
Most forecast models show the storm system will stay away from the East Coast of the U.S. as it strengthens in the mid-Atlantic.

title: Pee Dee residents return to flooded homes , cars after evacuating for Debby
message:
BENNETTSVILLE, SC (WMBF) - After leaving their homes during Tropical Storm Debby, residents returned to survey the damage left in the storm’s wake.
Covington was one of many residents who evacuated when they saw the water rising during Tropical Storm Debby last week.
“The reason why we left is because the water was coming out the creek and into the yard,” said Covington.
Covington has lived in Bennettsville for over 40 years and said Hurricane Hugo destroyed her home back in 1989.

title: Tropical storm Ernesto will dry us out this weekend
message:
Tropical storm Ernesto has developed east of the NE Caribbean and is expected to slowly consolidate into a hurricane once it passes the Islands.
A storm system or trough of low pressure off the coast of the mid Atlantic coast will keep Ernesto away from the mainland of the United States.
This will bring our rain chances down to less than 20%.
This weekend the rain chances go down below 20% for the coast and only 20% inland.

title: Nankei Trough advisory : Japan is bracing for a once - in - a - century earthquake . Does it need to ?
message:
A special committee warned that another “major earthquake” could hit in the coming week – the first time in its history the body had issued this type of nationwide advisory.
Then there’s the looming threat of the Nankai Trough megathrust earthquake – the most powerful of its kind, with magnitudes that can exceed 9.
Japan’s government has warned of the possible Nankai Trough quake for so many years that the possibility of it occurring has become common knowledge.
The ‘big one’The Nankai Trough is a 700-kilometer long (435-mile) subduction zone, which refers to when tectonic plates slip beneath each other.
“I tell (my students), the Nankai Trough earthquake will definitely come, whether it’s your generation or your children’s generation,” he said.

title: It so bad and so heartbreaking : River flooding affecting Pee Dee homeowners after Debby
message:
MARION COUNTY, SC (WMBF) -The town of Nichols continues to cope with the aftereffects of Tropical Storm Debby.
Rogers said the town had an opportunity to get ahead of some of the issues with flooding with preventative measures.
Down the road, Bernice Britt is used to traveling the Little Pee Dee River in a boat but is now wading through the water in her front yard.
After consulting a few friends, Britt said she decided to self-evacuate as the river continues to rise.
The WMBF First Alert Weather Team continues to monitor the river levels, the latest details can be found here.

title: Get ready for more wildfires and hurricanes : Environment Canada
message:
Human-caused climate change is making heat waves much more likely, the federal government says, bringing extreme weather from fires to storms.
That's according to Environment and Climate Change Canada's rapid extreme weather event attribution system, which compares today's climate to a pre-industrial one.
Natural Resources Minister Jonathan Wilkinson said there will be more wildfires from British Columbia to Manitoba this month, with climate change fuelling them.
"It is not unusual for Western Canada to see high levels of fire activity this time of year," he said at a press conference on Monday.
Get ready for more floods, fires and hurricanes as climate change clobbers Canada.
event_breakdown:
extreme weather events, floods, fires, hurricanes
Canada is grappling with an unprecedented number of extreme weather events, according to Environment Canada.
- A heat wave is sweeping the country, with temperatures expected to reach into the 40s in some areas.
- Flooding has caused widespread damage in southern Ontario, Quebec and New Brunswick.
- Fires are burning out of control in British Columbia, Alberta and Saskatchewan.
- The hurricane season is expected to be more active than usual.

event_breakdown:
Tropical Storm Ernesto
Puerto Rico activated the National Guard and canceled the start of classes in public schools as forecasters warned that the U.S. territory would be hit by Tropical Storm Ernesto, which formed in the Atlantic Ocean on Monday.  The National Weather Service issued a tropical storm warning for Puerto Rico and the U.S. Virgin Island, as well as issued hazardous weather outlook for the U.S. Virgin Islands, the Turks and Caicos, and the Southeast Bahamas. Tropical Storm Ernesto, which was located near St. Martin and north of Puerto Rico on the morning of August 9, brought winds of 50 mph (85 kph) to Puerto Rico that afternoon with a wind gust of 56 mph (90 kph) reported on the island of Culebra. As of 6 p.m. ET, Tropical Storm Ernesto was about 50 miles east-northeast of San Juan, Puerto Rico, with maximum sustained winds of 50 mph and a minimum central pressure of 1004 mb (hectopascals). Some strengthening is forecast during the next 48 hours. Tropical Storm Ernesto is expected to produce over 12 inches of rain across Puerto Rico and the Virgin Island through Friday, with eight inches expected across the remainder of the Virgin Islands and the Greater Antilles (including Puerto Rico) and the Dominican Republic.

title: Do you remember  Four in  04 ? 10 years ago , four hurricanes hit Florida in six weeks – NBC 6 South Florida
message:
The Hurricane season is on.
The 2004 Hurricane season delivered four hits to Florida in a matter of 6 weeks.
Hurricane Jeanne became the sixth major hurricane of the relentless 2004 season, making landfall on the Florida’s Treasure Coast, Sept. 25.
Use this knowledge today and for everyone storm season ahead.
Yet, more importantly, it’s a reminder that hurricane season can be unforgiving.

title: EMO to meet as Tropical Storm Ernesto strengthens
message:
Tropical Storm Ernesto, previously known as Potential Tropical Cyclone Five, was situated in the southern Caribbean when the Bermuda Weather Service issued its 6pm update, with maximum sustained winds of about 46mph.
By early Wednesday morning, Ernesto was expected to strengthen into a strong tropical storm and move over the US and British Virgin Islands and Puerto Rico.
The US National Hurricane Centre said today that tropical storm warnings were in effect for the Leeward Islands, the Virgin Islands and Puerto Rico.
Despite weakening into a tropical storm immediately after passing over Florida, the storm unleashed floods and tornadoes, and has so far claimed seven lives and created about $12 billion worth of damages.

title: 4 . 4 magnitude earthquake hits Los Angeles area
message:
A powerful earthquake struck near Los Angeles, California on Monday afternoon, shaking homes and startling residents for miles.
The 4.4 magnitude quake's epicentre hit near Highland Park, a neighbourhood in Los Angeles County not far from the famous Hollywood sign and the Griffith Observatory, at around 12:20 PST (20:20 BST), according to the US Geological Survey.
The Los Angeles Fire Department said crews from the city's 106 fire stations were doing a complete survey of the Greater Los Angeles area for structural damage or other issues.
The earthquake was first estimated as a 4.7 magnitude, but was later downgraded to a 4.4 magnitude by the US Geological Survey.
The area has seen several magnitude 4 and 5 earthquakes in recent weeks, including in Grapevine and Bakersfield, California last week.
event_breakdown: Highland Park, California, USA

message:

title: Two Strong Earthquakes Hit Maluku Region in Eight Hours , No Tsunami Potential
message:
TEMPO.CO, Jakarta - The Meteorology, Climatology, and Geophysics Agency (BMKG) reported that two strong earthquakes with a magnitude of 5.0 and above rocked Maluku and North Maluku with an interval of about eight hours.
The first earthquake hit the Batang Dua Island area, Ternate, North Maluku, on Monday evening, August 12, 2024, at 06:36 p.m. WIB (Western Indonesia Time).
"By considering the epicenter and hypocenter, the earthquake was a medium earthquake due to rock deformation activity in the Maluku Sea Plate.
Meanwhile, in the early hours of Tuesday, August 13, 2024, a 5.3 magnitude earthquake jolted the Banda Sea area, West Seram, Maluku.
Based on the estimated shakemap, this earthquake caused tremors in the Amahai, Damer, and Huamual areas with an intensity scale of III MMI.

title: Puerto Rico cancels classes , activates National Guard as Tropical Storm Ernesto approaches
message:
SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico — Puerto Rico activated the National Guard and canceled the start of classes in public schools as forecasters warned that the U.S. territory would be hit by Tropical Storm Ernesto, which formed in the Atlantic Ocean on Monday.
Tropical storm warnings were in effect for Puerto Rico, Vieques, Culebra, the U.S. and British Virgin Islands, Antigua, Barbuda, Anguilla, St. Kitts, Nevis, Montserrat, Guadeloupe, St. Martin, St. Barts and St. Maarten.

title: Japan is bracing for a once - in - a - century earthquake
message:
A special committee warned that another “major earthquake” could hit in the coming week – the first time in its history the body had issued this type of nationwide advisory.
Then there’s the looming threat of the Nankai Trough megathrust earthquake – the most powerful of its kind, with magnitudes that can exceed 9.
Japan’s government has warned of the possible Nankai Trough quake for so many years that the possibility of it occurring has become common knowledge.
The Nankai Trough is a 700-kilometer long (435-mile) subduction zone, which refers to when tectonic plates slip beneath each other.
“I tell (my students), the Nankai Trough earthquake will definitely come, whether it’s your generation or your children’s generation,” he said.
location: The Nankai Trough is located in Japan.

title: Did much - needed rain from Debby alleviate drought conditions in DC area ?
message:
Debby brought much-needed rain to the D.C. area, but not enough to pull it out of the ongoing drought.
Debby brought much-needed rain to the D.C. area, but not enough to pull it out of the ongoing drought.
At the Point of Rocks gauge, the ICPRB monitored a threshold of 1,740 cubic feet per second right before the storm.
Whenever it drops to below 2,000 cubic feet per second, the commission goes into daily drought monitoring.
However, that threshold surged to 61,000 cubic feet per second during the peak of the storm, and has now subsided to about 18,000 cubic feet per second.

title: Quake warning - The Statesman
message:
The magnitude 7.1 quake was quickly followed by a warning from Japan’s meteorological agency, a first in the country’s history, indicating an increased risk of a major earthquake.
Experts warn that there is a high probability of another massive quake occurring in this area within the next few decades.
The alert was not based on concrete evidence that a large quake was imminent, but rather on a statistical increase in the likelihood of one occurring.
In a region where the consequences of a major earthquake could be catastrophic, even a small increase in preparedness can make a significant difference.
It is a call to action for both authorities and citizens alike to ensure that they are as prepared as possible for the next major seismic event ~ whether it comes tomorrow or years from now.
event_breakdown:
Haiti has been hit by a magnitude 7.2 earthquake, causing widespread damage. The quake was centered about 12 kilometers (7.5 miles) west of Port-au-prince at a depth of 10 kilometers (6 miles), the U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) reported. It was one of the strongest quakes to hit Haiti in nearly a decade.

According to local authorities, more than 18 people died in building collapses, while many others were killed in landslides. Large parts of Haiti have been left without electricity or telephone service.

Rescue teams have been deployed to the affected areas to assist those affected by the quake. The USGS has issued a tsunami warning for Haiti, Cuba, and the Cayman Islands.

title: National Weather Service Confirms Tornado Hit Ulster County
message:
The National Weather Service confirms at least one tornado touched in the parts of the Hudson Valley Friday afternoon.
National Weather Service Confirms Tornado Hit Parts of Ulster CountyThe National Weather Service says an EF-0 tornado touched down and crossed the New York State Thruway late Friday afternoon.
NBC says the tornado touched down near Exit 18 on the Thruway.
While there was no tornado warning issued, this was more than likely the same storm that prompted a tornado warning in Orange County earlier Friday, reports meteorologists.
The National Weather Service says July 2024 set an all-time record for tornadoes in New York for one month.
event_breakdown: The National Weather Service confirms at least one tornado touched down in the parts of the Hudson Valley late Friday afternoon.

title: National Hurricane Center officially unveils new  experimental  cone
message:
ORLANDO, Fla. – Earlier this year, the National Hurricane Center announced that it would test a new ”experimental” cone by the middle of the Atlantic hurricane season.
The experimental cone is geared to help highlight the far-reaching impacts of a storm rather than just show the track of the center of the storm, which is what the traditional cone shows.
The experimental cone will also have inland watches and warnings overlaid to better show who will be impacted by the storm.
The cone being “experimental” in the eyes of the National Weather Service means simply means that a potential new product is being tested by them.
There click on the large red text for the new experimental cone.

title: Storm dumps intense rainfall on northern Japan , sending some people to shelters - New Delhi Times - India Only International Newspaper
message:
A slow-moving storm has been dumping intense rains on northern Japan, swelling rivers, sending residents to shelters and disrupting traffic during a Japanese Buddhist holiday week.
The storm was once Typhoon Maria but has weakened, with winds now blowing up to 72 kph (45 mph).
It made landfall near Ofunato City in Iwate prefecture Monday morning and was expected to cut across the Tohoku region as it moved northwest at 20 kph (12 mph), according to the Japan Meteorological Agency.
Iwate prefecture said about 2,000 people actually took shelter early Monday.
This storm is the first to make landfall in the Tohoku region since the 2016 typhoon.

title: Jean Lafitte residents adapt to life on the edge of survival
message:
“He said, I’m committed to helping you.”Kerner, 33, presides as mayor over Jean Lafitte.
Outside the federal hurricane protection system, Jean Lafitte faces a deluge of rising sea levels, strengthening storms and skyrocketing insurance prices.
For Jean Lafitte residents, the spending constitutes their fight for existence.
Tides of changeThe town’s namesake comes from privateer Jean Lafitte, whose schooners homeported to the south in Barataria Bay.
The Kerners, like many longtime Lafitte residents, proudly trace their origins to Manila Village, widely considered the first Asian settlement in the United States.
event_breakdown: Jean Lafitte is facing a deluge of rising sea levels, strengthening storms, and skyrocketing insurance prices.

title: Tropical Storm Ernesto eyes Puerto Rico while plowing through Caribbean islands
message:
CNN —Tropical Storm Ernesto is slamming the northern Caribbean with heavy rain, gusty winds and rough seas Tuesday as it sets up to take a swipe at Puerto Rico.
Satellite imagery captures Tropical Storm Ernesto churning over the northeastern Caribbean as the sun rises Tuesday morning.
Tropical storm warnings are in effect for Puerto Rico and the Leeward Islands, including the US and British Virgin Islands.
Rainfall totals of 4 to 6 inches will be widespread, with up to 10 inches possible in parts of Puerto Rico.
Flash flooding and mudslides are possible as a result, especially in the higher terrain areas of eastern and southern Puerto Rico.

title: Tropical Storm Ernesto expected to hit Puerto Rico and the Virgin Islands before strengthening into hurricane
message:
Tropical Storm Ernesto has formed in the Atlantic Ocean — just days after Debby finished its trek along the U.S. East Coast — and is expected to hit near or over the Virgin Islands and Puerto Rico on Tuesday evening, the National Hurricane Center says.
It is expected to move across the Leeward Islands on Tuesday morning, which includes the islands in the northeastern Caribbean, and will be near or over the U.S. and British Virgin Islands and Puerto Rico by the evening.
Satellite imagery shows Tropical Storm Ernesto on a path toward the Virgin Islands and Puerto Rico on Aug. 13.
National Hurricane CenterThe storm is expected to produce between 4 and 6 inches of rain over the Leeward and Virgin Islands, and 3 to 6 inches, and maximum amounts of 10 inches, over Puerto Rico.
The Leeward Islands could also see "considerable flash flooding and mudslides," the National Hurricane Center said.

title: The state rep who sparked Colorado fire recovery - Grist
message:
Hello, and welcome back to State of Emergency, a limited-run newsletter about how disasters are reshaping our politics.
A focus on fireKyle Brown was the lead sponsor on 26 bills during his first term as a Colorado state representative, and half of those concerned either the Marshall Fire recovery or future fire resilience.
The hurricane also brought flooding to Tampa as early voting began in Florida state primaries.
Read moreTim Walz, climate veep: Minnesota governor Tim Walz hails from a state that is immune from many big climate disasters, such as hurricanes and wildfires.
But as my State of Emergency co-writer reports, Kamala Harris’ running mate has an impressive record of passing big green laws in his purple state.

title: Tropical Storm Ernesto drenches northeast Caribbean and takes aim at Puerto Rico
message:
Tropical Storm Ernesto drenches northeast Caribbean and takes aim at Puerto Rico View PhotoSAN JUAN, Puerto Rico (AP) — Tropical Storm Ernesto battered the northeast Caribbean on Tuesday as it took aim at Puerto Rico, where officials shuttered schools and government agencies.
The storm was located about 300 miles (480 kilometers) east-southeast of San Juan, Puerto Rico, on Tuesday morning.
The looming rains come as Puerto Rico faces six reservoirs that already were overflowing ahead of the storm.
The National Hurricane Center said Ernesto is forecast to move over or near Puerto Rico and the U.S. and British Virgin Islands on Tuesday evening.
“That’s a reality,” said Juan Saca, president of Luma Energy, a private company that operates the transmission and distribution of power in Puerto Rico.

title: Photos show massive wildfire raging in Greece as residents near Athens forced to flee homes
message:
Hundreds of European firefighters, backed by fire engines and waterbombing aircraft, have sought to contain the country's worst wildfire this year.

title: Puerto Rico Braces for Tropical Storm Ernesto
message:
Puerto Rico has activated the National Guard and canceled the start of classes in public schools as forecasters warned that the U.S. territory would be hit by Tropical Storm Ernesto, which formed in the Atlantic Ocean on Monday.
Tropical storm warnings were in effect for Puerto Rico and the Virgin Islands.
Ernesto's maximum sustained winds are 45 mph, according to the National Hurricane Center.
The storm is expected to spin out into the central Atlantic away from the US Mainland.

title: Japan is bracing for a once - in - a - century earthquake . Does it need to ?
message:
A special committee warned that another “major earthquake” could hit in the coming week – the first time in its history the body had issued this type of nationwide advisory.
Then there’s the looming threat of the Nankai Trough megathrust earthquake – the most powerful of its kind, with magnitudes that can exceed 9.
Japan’s government has warned of the possible Nankai Trough quake for so many years that the possibility of it occurring has become common knowledge.
However, he had no doubt that “a major earthquake will occur in this area” in the future.
“I tell (my students), the Nankai Trough earthquake will definitely come, whether it’s your generation or your children’s generation,” he said.

message:

title: Tropical Storm Ernesto tracking toward Leeward Islands , Puerto Rico
message:
Tropical Storm Ernesto a little stronger as it passes just south of St. Kitts, NevisTAMPA, Fla. - Newly formed Tropical Storm Ernesto is tracking toward the Leeward Islands and Puerto Rico as it continues to gather strength, according to the NHC.
According to the National Hurricane Center, Ernesto is passing just south of St. Kitts and Nevis.
A hurricane watch has been issued for the Virgin Islands, Vieques, and Culebra.
The storm should take a sharp turn northwest, though, after churning through Puerto Rico and the Leeward Islands and stay over open waters in the Atlantic.
Heavy rainfall may result in ‘locally considerable’ flash flooding and mudslides in areas of the Leeward Islands through Tuesday and over the Virgin Islands into Puerto Rico by later Tuesday through Wednesday, according to the NHC.

title: Tropical Storm Ernesto hits Caribbean , heads to Puerto Rico
message:
By DÁNICA COTO, The Associated PressSAN JUAN, Puerto Rico (AP) — Tropical Storm Ernesto battered the northeast Caribbean on Tuesday as it took aim at Puerto Rico, where officials shuttered schools and government agencies.
The storm was located about 300 miles east-southeast of San Juan, Puerto Rico, on Tuesday morning.
The looming rains come as Puerto Rico faces six reservoirs that already were overflowing ahead of the storm.
Tropical storm warnings were in place for Puerto Rico, Vieques, Culebra, the U.S. and British Virgin Islands, St. Kitts, Nevis, Montserrat, Antigua, Barbuda, Anguilla, Guadeloupe, St. Martin, St. Barts and St. Maarten.
(NOAA via AP)APThe National Hurricane Center said Ernesto is forecast to move over or near Puerto Rico and the U.S. and British Virgin Islands on Tuesday evening.
event_breakdown: Tropical Storm Ernesto is battering the northeast Caribbean, with Puerto Rico in its sights. The storm was 300 miles east-southeast of San Juan on Tuesday morning. The island has faced six overflowing reservoirs ahead of Ernesto. Hurricane warnings are in place for the U.S. Virgin Islands and Puerto Rico.

Tropical Storm Ernesto is approaching Puerto Rico and is expected to become a hurricane within the next 24 hours, the US National Hurricane Center in Miami said in an advisory Tuesday morning. Heavy rains and strong winds are already lashing the island as people rush to secure homes and businesses.

Ernesto could become a category 2 hurricane (104-110 mph), according to the National Hurricane Center.

Ernesto will be the third major hurricane this year in the Atlantic.



Cat 5 Ernesto hits US Virgin Islands

Southeastern United States threatened by strengthening Ernesto

Ernesto makes landfall in Jamaica

Ernesto may well become a hurricane before it reaches Puerto Rico, according to the US National Weather Service. The Weather Channel is also predicting that Ernesto will reach hurricane strength as it comes closer to Puerto Rico.

Ernesto is forecast to pass over or very close to the southern Puerto Rico and Hispaniola as it moves through the eastern Caribbean Sea.

In the advisory, the NHC said, “A dangerous storm surge will raise water levels by 2-4 feet above normal tide levels in the hurricane warning area near and to the north of the center of Ernesto.  A storm surge warning is in effect for portions of the south and southeast coasts of Puerto Rico.

"It will also be accompanied by violent winds, at times causing scattered power outages, numerous downed trees and structural damage, even in highly populated areas.

 “At least 6-12 inches of rain are possible in some areas, leading to possible flash flooding,” the NHC said in the advisory.

title: Gainesville begins mosquito spraying to control rising numbers after Hurricane Debby
message:
Local mosquito populations already on the rise prior to the arrival of Hurricane Debby are finding new breeding grounds in standing water left behind by the storm.
Last week, the city of Gainesville’s Mosquito Control division began spraying for mosquitoes throughout Gainesville and are expected to continue spraying this week.
For residents with retention ponds on their property, the division provides mosquito fish, free of charge.
The Mosquito Control division actively monitors and treats more than 650 breeding sites throughout Gainesville for mosquito larvae including retention ponds, roadside ditches, low-lying regions and areas prone to flooding.
This article originally appeared on The Gainesville Sun: Gainesville begins mosquito spraying after rains from Hurricane Debby

event_breakdown: The National Hurricane Center issued its last advisory on Tropical Storm Ernesto Thursday, August 2 at 5:00 PM HST. The system had degenerated into a mass of deep convection with no circulation and max winds of 35 mph about 100 miles southeast of Manzanillo, Mexico. The convection is expected to ride the south side of a deep-layer ridge across the western Gulf of Mexico on a northeastward trajectory. This low is not a threat to land areas, but environmental conditions could become marginally conducive for regeneration over the western Gulf of Mexico late Friday or into Saturday.

title: Tropical Storm Ernesto expected to strengthen into a hurricane on path to Bermuda
message:
Tropical Storm Ernesto will be bringing heavy rain, strong winds and rough surf to Puerto Rico and the U.S. and British Virgin Islands in the next two days before strengthening into a hurricane and curving north and east toward Bermuda by this weekend, forecasters said.
Tropical storm warnings — indicating tropical storm conditions are expected within 36 hours — are active in Anguilla, Antigua, Barbuda, Barthelemy, Culebra, Guadeloupe, Montserrat, Nevis, St. Barthelemy, St. Kitts, St. Martin, Sint Maarten, the British Virgin Islands, the U.S. Virgin Islands, Puerto Rico and Vieques.
“On the forecast track, Ernesto is expected to move across portions of the Leeward Islands this morning and near or over the U.S. and British Virgin Islands and Puerto Rico by this evening,” the hurricane center said in its latest storm advisory.
“After passing Puerto Rico and the Virgin Islands, Ernesto is forecast to turn northward over the western Atlantic,” the agency added.
As of now, Ernesto — which strengthened into a tropical storm Monday evening and became the fifth named storm of the 2024 hurricane season — is not expected to have any direct impacts on the eastern United States.

title: Lahaina wildfire anniversary highlights need for consistent , long - term , disaster recovery coverage by national TV news
message:
The Lahaina wildfire, which started on August 8, 2023, devastated the historic town of Lahaina, Hawaii, on Maui’s coast, claiming over 100 lives and destroying more than 2,000 structures.
As one of the deadliest wildfires in recent U.S. history, it left the community grappling with immense loss and facing significant challenges in recovery.
The fire exacerbated pre-existing issues like housing shortages and economic dependence on tourism while also highlighting the region's vulnerability to climate-related disasters.
The disaster has also raised concerns about how to preserve Lahaina's rich cultural heritage during the rebuilding process.
The community is actively involved in discussions about Lahaina's future, with a focus on honoring its cultural history and improving resilience against future disasters.

title: Tropical Storm Ernesto expected to strengthen into a hurricane by Thursday
message:
SAN JUAN – Tropical Storm Ernesto on Tuesday threatened to bring heavy rainfall, dangerous storm surges and strong winds to the US, British Virgin Islands and Puerto Rico, leading the US territory to close schools and prepare for power outages.
The storm, last observed northwest of the island of Guadalupe and carrying maximum winds of 45 miles per hour (75 km per hour), could strengthen into a hurricane by Thursday after passing over Puerto Rico and veering north into the Atlantic, the National Hurricane Center said.
Ernesto – the fifth named storm of the season – is expected to miss Florida and the US Southeast, which are still reeling from Tropical Storm Debby.
Like Debby, Ernesto’s greatest threat is torrential rain, which could spur flash floods and landslides, especially in the mountainous interior of Puerto Rico and nearby Caribbean islands.
On Monday, Puerto Rico Governor Pedro Pierluisi activated more than 200 National Guard members and expedited food benefits for families ahead of the storm’s arrival.
event_breakdown: Tropical Storm Ernesto threatened to bring heavy rainfall, dangerous storm surges and strong winds to the US, British Virgin Islands and Puerto Rico on Tuesday, leading the US territory to close schools and prepare for power outages, officials said. Ernesto - the fifth named storm of the season - is expected to miss Florida and the US Southeast.

title: 4 . 4 magnitude earthquake hits Los Angeles area
message:
A powerful earthquake struck near Los Angeles, California on Monday afternoon, shaking homes and startling residents for miles.
The 4.4 magnitude quake's epicentre hit near Highland Park, a neighbourhood in Los Angeles County not far from the famous Hollywood sign and the Griffith Observatory, at around 12:20 PST (20:20 BST), according to the US Geological Survey.
The Los Angeles Fire Department said crews from the city's 106 fire stations were doing a complete survey of the Greater Los Angeles area for structural damage or other issues.
The earthquake was first estimated as a 4.7 magnitude, but was later downgraded to a 4.4 magnitude by the US Geological Survey.
The area has seen several magnitude 4 and 5 earthquakes in recent weeks, including in Grapevine and Bakersfield, California last week.

title: First Alert Weather In - Depth : Name retirement is not necessarily a good thing
message:
ROCHESTER, N.Y. — When you see the timeline of an average season for tropical storms and hurricanes, you will notice the heart of the tropical season is approaching quickly.
The year with the most retired names was 2005 when five storms were retired.
An example how different a season can be was back in 2018 when Hurricane Florence and Hurricane Michael made landfall.
The other side of the spectrum was Hurricane Michael which made landfall is a category five storm with winds of 160 mph.
Looking ahead the next tropical system we are looking for Tropical Storm Ernesto.

The storm is expected to move near or over the U.S. Virgin islands Tuesday evening before passing north-northeast of Puerto Rico later that day into early Wednesday.
“We expect Ernesto to be a strong tropical storm as it interacts with Puerto Rico late Tuesday night to Wednesday,” said Alex DaSilva, lead hurricane expert with AccuWeather.
Flash flooding and mudslides were possible in the more elevated areas of southern and eastern Puerto Rico.
Albert Bryan Jr., governor of the U.S. Virgin Islands, said people needed to take Ernesto seriously, The Associated Press reported.

title: Update | Tropical Storm Ernesto drenches northeast Caribbean and takes aim at Puerto Rico
message:
SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico (AP) — Tropical Storm Ernesto battered the northeast Caribbean on Tuesday as it took aim at Puerto Rico, where officials shuttered schools, opened shelters and helped move dozens of the US territory's endangered parrots into hurricane-proof rooms.
The storm is forecast to move over or near the US Virgin Islands on Tuesday evening and pass just northeast and north of Puerto Rico late Tuesday and early Wednesday.
Heavy rains began pelting Puerto Rico before the storm, and strong winds churned the ocean into a milky turquoise as people rushed to finish securing their homes and businesses.
The looming rains come as Puerto Rico faces six reservoirs that already were overflowing before the storm.
Tropical storm warnings were in place for Puerto Rico, St Kitts, Nevis, Montserrat, Antigua, Barbuda, Anguilla, Guadeloupe, St Martin, St Barts and St Maarten.

title: Ernesto is strengthening as it plows through Caribbean islands . Here where it could go next and how strong it could get .
message:
CNN(CNN) — Tropical Storm Ernesto is strengthening as it slams the northern Caribbean with heavy rain, gusty winds and rough seas Tuesday and approaches Puerto Rico.
Ernesto could become a hurricane while it tracks just north of Puerto Rico early Wednesday.
Tropical storm warnings are in effect for Puerto Rico and the Leeward Islands, including the US and British Virgin Islands.
Rainfall totals of 4 to 6 inches will be widespread, with up to 10 inches possible in parts of Puerto Rico.
Flash flooding and mudslides are possible as a result, especially in the higher terrain areas of eastern and southern Puerto Rico.

title: Puerto Rico activates National Guard as Tropical Storm Ernesto approaches
message:
Puerto Rico activated the National Guard and canceled the start of classes in public schools as forecasters warned that the U.S. territory would be hit by Tropical Storm Ernesto, which formed in the Atlantic Ocean on Monday.
Tropical storm warnings were in effect for Puerto Rico, the U.S. and British Virgin Islands, Antigua, Barbuda, Anguilla, St. Kitts, Nevis, Montserrat, Guadeloupe, St. Martin, St. Barts and St. Maarten.
The National Hurricane Center said Ernesto is forecast to move over or near Puerto Rico and the U.S. and British Virgin Islands on Tuesday afternoon or evening.
Puerto Rico Governor Pedro Pierluisi said more than 340 shelters across the island would be available if necessary and that more than 200 personnel with the National Guard were activated.
“That's a reality,” said Juan Saca, president of Luma Energy, a private company that operates the transmission and distribution of power in Puerto Rico.

Tropical Storm Ernesto - Puerto Rico

title: Drought is top threat for united kingdom nature refuges as climate changes , charities warn
message:
Over the next 30 years, Wildlife Trusts experts believe drought will continue to pose the biggest threat to their reserves, with other climate-driven risks including heatwaves and wildfires also causes for high concern.
The Wildlife Trusts warned that flooding, rather than drought, is often at the top of the list of hazards that politicians and governments use to discuss climate impacts.
Drought planning needs more urgent attention alongside the other key hazards associated with climate change, the report urges.
To protect against worsening extremes, The Wildlife Trusts say they are taking action across their reserves to make these important habitats for nature more resilient to the changing climate.
“We will better protect our landscapes and wildlife by taking robust action to prepare for the impacts of a changing climate.”

Early on Friday, August 12, 2016, lots of heavy rain with impressive rainfall rates began to spread inland.
Although rain rates moderated for the rest of the day, rain continued.

title: Map shows Tropical Storm Ernesto paths including one targeting Florida | US News
message:
Tropical Storm Ernesto is the fifth storm to form in the 2024 Atlantic hurricane season (Pictures: USA Today/NOAA)The fifth storm of the 2024 Atlantic hurricane season, Tropical Storm Ernesto, is heading toward the Caribbean islands and possibly the US again.
Ernesto formed on Monday and moved toward Puerto Rico and the US Virgin Islands, possibly bringing stormy conditions to them by Tuesday, according to some forecasts.
That model shared by NOAA shows most of the predicted paths for Ernesto passing through Puerto Rico then swinging northeast into the western Atlantic Ocean area.
Tropical Storm Ernesto formed on Monday (Picture: AP)In the Atlantic, Ernesto is forecast to strengthen into a hurricane on Thursday, per the National Hurricane Center.
Puerto Rico has activated the National Guard and canceled the start of public school classes.
event_breakdown:
Tropical Storm Ernesto formed on Monday and is headed toward the Caribbean islands and possibly the US again.
Puerto Rico has activated the National Guard and canceled the start of public school classes.

title: Peace River dangerously close to overflowing , City of Bartow to host community meeting
message:
Hurricane Debby dropped a lot of water on Polk County and now the Peace River is dangerously close to overflowing.
And if more rain comes, some neighborhoods in the city of Bartow and its wastewater treatment plant could get flooded.
Because of all the rain, the Peace River is at an elevated level and more water is still on the way.
They're also coming up with preparations to protect the city's wastewater treatment plant which is located on the east side close to the Peace River.
The city will be hosting a community meeting on Thursday, Aug. 15 for residents in the neighborhoods prone to flooding.
event_breakdown: Polk County threatened by flooding

title: Tropical Storm Ernesto Forecast to Become Hurricane Ernesto by Wednesday
message:
The National Hurricane Center forecasts Tropical Storm Ernesto will become the third Atlantic hurricane of the season by Wednesday morning.
The 2024 Atlantic hurricane season is still forecast to be an exceptionally active system, as experts from Colorado State University'sTropical Weather & Climate Research division outlined in their latest update to theirForecast for 2024 Hurricane Activity.
This anticipated exceptionally active season is due in part to near-record sea surface temperatures in the Atlantic, a key ingredient to tropical cyclone development.
Sea surface temperatures right now are at their second-highest levels ever, just behind 2023 levels since the end of July, but still several degrees above normal.
Ernesto became the fifth named storm of the 2024 Atlantic hurricane season, and the third hurricane just over a week after Hurricane Debby dumped torrential rains across the southeast United States and produced significant rounds of severe weather in the northeast.
location: Based on the text, there is no specific location identified for the main event.

title: Tropical Storm Ernesto batters northeast Caribbean and aims at Puerto Rico as it strengthens
message:
By DÁNICA COTO Associated PressSAN JUAN, Puerto Rico (AP) — Tropical Storm Ernesto battered the northeast Caribbean on Tuesday as it took aim at Puerto Rico, where officials closed schools, opened shelters and moved dozens of the U.S. territory’s endangered parrots into hurricane-proof rooms.
“Ernesto could be near or at hurricane strength in about 24 hours,” the U.S. National Hurricane Center in Miami said in an advisory late Tuesday morning.
Tropical storm warnings were in place for Puerto Rico, St. Kitts, Nevis, Montserrat, Anguilla, St. Martin, St. Barts and St. Maarten.
Heavy rains began pelting Puerto Rico, and strong winds churned the ocean into a milky turquoise as people rushed to finish securing homes and businesses.
Ernesto Rodríguez with the National Weather Service warned that the storm’s trajectory could change as it approaches Puerto Rico.
event_breakdown: Tropical Storm Ernesto battered the northeast Caribbean on Tuesday as it took aim at Puerto Rico, where officials closed schools, opened shelters and moved dozens of the U.S. territory’s endangered parrots into hurricane-proof rooms.

title: Maps Show Which Texas Cities Will Be Under Water in 50 Years
message:
Get our free mobile appScientists are deeply concerned about rising sea levels along Texas' coast.
Rising sea levels pose a significant threat to Texas' coastal communities, infrastructure, and ecosystems.
Texas' coastal economy, which includes industries such as fishing, tourism, and shipping, is vulnerable to the impacts of sea-level rise, as well.
Credit: Climate Center Credit: Climate Central loading...A lot of cities along the Texas coast could be at risk of being underwater in 25 years, scientific maps at Climate Central predict.

title: Holyoke organization assists families as Tropical Storm Ernesto moves towards Puerto Rico
message:
(WGGB/WSHM) - Tropical Storm Ernesto is currently gaining steam in the Caribbean, and could become a hurricane as it tracks just north of Puerto Rico by Wednesday.
Officials in Puerto Rico have activated the National Guard and cancelled classes in the public schools in preparation for Ernesto.
Western Mass News spoke with a local organization with who said they’re ready to lend a helping hand if needed.
Tropical Storm Ernesto, bringing heavy rain, storm surge and gusty wind to the Caribbean on Tuesday as it approaches the U.S. and British Virgin Islands and Puerto Rico.
Western Mass News stopped by the local Holyoke organization Enlace de Familias, to learn how they assist those coming in from the islands during these types of situations.
event_breakdown:
- Tropical Storm Ernesto is currently gaining steam in the Caribbean, and could become a hurricane as it tracks just north of Puerto Rico by Wednesday.
- Officials in Puerto Rico have activated the National Guard and cancelled classes in the public schools in preparation for Ernesto.

title: UPDATE : Belville and NCDOT work to help alleviate flooding following Debby
message:
UPDATE: Belville and NCDOT work to help alleviate flooding following DebbyNCDOT and the Town of Belville are working together to help alleviate flooding caused by the significant rainfall from Tropical Storm Debby.
(Photo: Town of Belville)BELVILLE, NC (WWAY) — We have new details on a story WWAY brought you Monday night concerning flooding in Belville following Tropical Storm Debby.
On Tuesday, the NC Department of Transportation and Town of Belville began working to address flooded areas within the community.
Currently, NCDOT crews are on-site at the intersection of River Birch Ridge Court and Two Pine Road, where they are working to alleviate the flooding caused by the storm’s downpour.
“We’re happy to assist the Town of Belville in abatement efforts and are eager to see this work benefit the residents of Belville and Northern Brunswick County,” Carroll said.

ANSWER:
The main location for this event is Belville, North Carolina.
